nodes.text: A decision tree based machine learning model can classify and predict diabetes status from patient data
Diabetes is a growing global health problem with increasing prevalence and mortality motivating automated diagnostic tools
We used the Pima Indians Diabetes dataset of 768 patient instances with 9 attributes to develop and test the model
We implemented a binary decision tree classifier using Python, Pandas and scikit-learn, trained and evaluated with different train/test splits and visualized the tree
Decision trees use impurity measures such as information entropy, Gini index and classification error to choose splits and can be pruned using error criteria
WHO and other sources report diabetes prevalence rose from 108 million in 1980 to 422 million in 2014 and global prevalence among adults increased from 4.7% to 8.5%
Data cleaning removed records with physiologically impossible zero values in Glucose, BloodPressure, and BMI, reducing erroneous entries before training
Feature importance assessment is necessary because some dataset features have greater impact on classification and some may be unobservable to users
We performed three experiments with different train/test splits: 70/30, 50/50, and 30/70 to evaluate model performance under varying training data sizes
Model training produced evaluation outputs including accuracy estimates, classification reports and confusion matrices for each experiment
The 50% training and 50% testing split yielded the highest reported accuracy of 0.71 among the tested splits
Increasing the proportion of data allocated to training generally improved accuracy estimates in our experiments
Based on experiments, the best configuration in this study was a 50/50 train/test split giving accuracy 0.71
Advantages of the decision tree diagnostic model include fast training, intuitive rule generation, nonparametric modeling and prediction accuracy comparable to other analysis methods
The implemented Python software package provides a decision tree based diagnostic tool that requires medical consultation for final diagnosis
Study limitations include reliance on a single open dataset and potential data quality issues from removed zero-valued entries
